subject: Life Is...
event:
... meaningless and full of pain... but sometimes it gives you an unexpected gift.

The Giants game was a disgrace.  Bill Sheridan has to go.  How he could destroy the Giants defense in a single year, when he had all the players Steve Spagnuolo had and then some, is a mystery for the ages.

And the Jets... well, yeah, I'm glad they got the W, but really... call me old school, but I believe a team should play hard every week, no matter what.  What Caldwell did was a disgrace.  A nice late Xmas present for Gang Green, sure, but all the other teams contending for the AFC wild card must be steaming, and Peyton and the other Colts first-stringers looked none too happy on the sidelines either.  I would not be the least surprised if the Happy Horseshoes make an early exit from the playoffs after this.  Disgraceful.

Meanwhile, back in the Meadowlands, I can only hope that the final Jets home game in Giants Stadium has a happier result than the final Giants home game.

comments.article:
I didn't get to see the game, but I did see the final score and was shocked to see the Colts hand over the game when they had such a perfect season. Disgraceful, indeed.

Jenn

The icing...would be if the Jets meet and beat the Colts in the playoffs knowing that the Jets might not have even gotten into the playoffs without the Colts bailing on yesterday's game.

If nothing else though, yesterday's game proved that Manning is the MVP of the league. The Colts can't do much without him...

As a Bronco fan I'm not so sure about the Colts resting everyone as being the fan of a team that starts 6-0 and then loses 7 of 8 to finish the season off and take the playoff destiny out of their hands. We should have beat the Raiders and Eagles. It was a heckuva comeback by the Broncos yesterday only to fold in the last minute. Still...

Go Raiders and Bengals next week!
Better than the Broncos!  I'm too ashamed to show my face.  I'll join you on the "sadness bench."

comments.upictitle: Eric: Ashley and Callo (Credit to furious)
comments.article: You know who I think Caldwell really may have destroyed here?  Curtis Painter.  This is what the poor guy may always be known for: being thrown to the wolves when his team is undefeated and having it all come crashing down around him.  The replay of that cataclysmic fumble has this dreadful longevity about it already.

comments.upictitle: Names Is For Tombstones, Baby: Rocketeer
comments.article: Yeah, I concur.  Poor bastard.

I was very disappointed with Caldwell's decision on the Colts-Jets game. Specially bad given that they were playing in Indy. Last game of the regular season in Indianapolis and he gave it away. They might have lost with Peyton, but at least they should keep playing.

I hear you about Sheridan. I don't think the main problem is that he's an inadequate strategist; rather, the man seems clueless about how to motivate people. His players seem to have have no loyalty or connection to him whatsoever, and as a result they don't give a consistent effort for him. You always saw Spags on the sidelines, building that emotional connection with his players and rooting them on. The writing was on the wall early this year when Sheridan asked to do his job from the booth upstairs instead of the sidelines. It was apparent then that he viewed his players as X's and O's to manipulate as opposed to flesh and blood people to motivate.
comments.subject: The Giants

comments.article: At least would be if I wasn't a Packer fan!! Woot! Go Pack!!
comments.subject: Yes, very sad...

comments.article: I thought for the first time all year, the Seahawks were going to show up.  Then Hasselbeck started throwing INT's, and I ended up off on my prediction of 38-7.  I've already joined a group writing letters to the Seahawks front office to fire the entire coaching staff and bring in a new approach and a new QB.  I'd rather be 3-13 next year in a rebuilding year than 5-11 this year in a season we were supposed to compete with the Cards for the NFC West title.
comments.subject: Re: Yes, very sad...

comments.article: I agree with you on the Colts.  Imagine how you'd feel if you'd paid for tickets to the game!  Terrible.

Got to disagree on Caldwell's decision. The right thing to do is keep your players healthy when the game has zero effect on the playoff picture. How is this different from sitting starters halfway through a preseason game?

This wasn't a preseason game.

The Colts have "rested their starters" before. Every time they did, they ended up getting eliminated in their first playoff.

On the other hand, the 2007 Giants went all out in their final game, one that meant nothing to their playoff seeding. They lost, but they also came out of that game psyched up for the playoffs, and went on to win the SuperBowl.

You play to win the game. You don't play to avoid injury.
Only things better than shutting out the Redskins is doing so AND knocking the Giants out of the playoff race! :)
comments.subject: Cowboys Up

comments.article:
The Panthers knocked out the G-Men, not the Cowboys.

Seems to me that we handled you twice this year.
comments.subject: Re: Cowboys Up

comments.article: Win some lose some George. How the heck do you beat us twice and then get blown out by the panthers? I guess we drove the nail in your playoff hopes with a win last night but someone had to put the Giants out of their misery it seems. Now I know you'll be cheering for us against the Eagles next Sunday (not!) :D
I was a Jets fan yesterday.

Caldwell should have looked at the history of the team before he made his decision.  It's pretty obvious that the Colts perform poorly in the playoffs when they take it easy at the end of the regular season.  When they won the Super Bowl, they had to play hard until the end of the season.  Caldwell should remember it because I believe he was there.

Maybe it's because I'm Mets fan as well, but the Giants' performance did not surprise me. The talking heads are all wondering how come they didn't play with more emotion. That was the issue. Manning was hassled all game. The offense can't run. Their was no pass rush. Their was no lane discipline. The LB corp are weak. The DBs are second and third stringers.

The Panthers are a decent team. They are well coached and better coordinated. The Giants coaching staff has, even since the days of Fassel, shown an inability to have a plan B.

This Giants team needs some serious reconstruction. Tom and Jerry showed they were up the task the prior two seasons. I think they will be up to the task this off-season. Bring out the wrecking ball.

Oh yeah, yay Jets? I really hope they don't win next week. The team will be better for it.

The Panthers started off poorly this season, but really had all the pieces left from last year's 12-4 team. Delhomme had the worst (and likely last) season of his career, and they had some injuries. Early in the year, Steve Smith wasn't getting the ball. The Defense was on the field too much, and even good defenses break down (see Pittsburgh). Also, I think the injury to DeAngelo Williams was a good thing, because it's finally forced Carolina to go with Stewart, who is like another Michael Turner. Williams is quick and can break off long runs, but Stewart has good speed and is like trying to tackle a wrecking ball. Finally, Matt Moore is the real deal at QB. With good balance on offense, the defense has the legs to maintain their pass rush and stop the run consistently. The Giants just got manhandled by a team looking for respect after a horrible start.  I wish the Seahawks could have pulled it together as well as the Panthers.

I can't believe what Caldwell did. You always go for history. I guess the '72 Dolphins can pop their champagne again. We here in Indy feel ashamed...even though it was not our fault and the decision of just one man. We now have no momentum. It'll serve us right to get knocked out in the first round.
comments.subject: Disgraced Colts fan

comments.article:
If the starters played and a key player was lost to injury everyone would be howling for Caldwell's head. Peyton doesn't get hurt - he gets rid of the ball too quickly, but I still think it's the money play.

Is it unfair to the other wild card contenders that the Jets got a free pass? Sure. Can the Jets advance in the playoffs? Not likely at all. Really, it's kind of cruel to the Jets who are most likely going to lose their first playoff game. The Colts earned the right to coast by going 14 and 0 in the first place. That's a pretty nice perk.

I'd make the same call Caldwell did, play your starters for the first half, let them get their reps in, find their rhythm and then protect them. 16 and 0 is meaningless to the Colts. The Superbowl is the real prize.

Uh, are you kidding? It is cruel for the jets to make the playoffs? The jets have no chance to beat the bengals in the playoffs? (after we beat them sunday nite to get into the playoffs) Dude, I know the entire country loves to dis the jets any chance you get, but they do own the #1 defence and the #1 offence. Fact. And it is not like mr manning was exactly lighting it up for the 2.75 quarters he was in the game. All due respect to pm and the colts (he is no doubt my choice for best all time) but this jet team has alot more going for it than anyone wants to give them credit for. We will make the playoffs this year and have a decent shot to win a game before we end up in SD or Indy. Next year, though, look out. This is a team on the way up. Our defense will be very scary next year and if Sanchez can grow up quickly.....
comments.subject: kind of cruel?

comments.article:
As a fan of one of the other teams fighting for a playoff spot in the AFC (the Broncos), I'm not angry at the Colts for hurting my team's chances. If the Broncos can't win a home game against the Raiders and JaMarcus friggin Russell, they don't belong in the playoffs anyway.

I am disappointed with Caldwell's decision, but that's more because I feel like he passed on a once in a lifetime opportunity. Winning a Super Bowl is a great achievement, but running the table would have cemented the 2009 Colts as an all-time great team. If Peyton were hurt or getting banged up or something, I'd understand, but pulling a perfectly healthy Peyton in a 5-point game isn't cool. And the fans in Indy were not happy with the decision either--you know, the fans who payed full-price for those tickets? Something tells me they aren't going to get a refund, even if the game evidently meant nothing to their team's head coach.
Manning said all the right things in backing his coaches decision, but you could tell by the look on his face on the sidelines that he was pretty upset.

As a jets fan I am not apologizing to anyone for our victory yesterday. Do I think we would have one if Manning had stayed in there for the whole game? Probably not, but lets remember that the jets had (briefly) a 3rd quarter lead on manning and company. I have seen enough football to know that nobody knows what would have happened if manning stayed in there. The jets do own the #1 defence and the #1 rushing attack. Yes, I would be angry if I was a Colts fan and my coach decided to not chase a perfect season. But any Fish fans or Bronco fans or Jags fans can go cry in their beer - your teams had their chances. We control our own destiny now and we will take it.
comments.subject: jets/colts

comments.article:
Last year: The Colts played hard throughout the season since the Titans won the division at 13-3. So they did what all the Jim Caldwell critics wanted them to do this year...and they lost in the first round to the 8-8 Chargers.

If Jeff Saturday gets injured, the Colts are significantly worse. If Dallas Clark gets injured, they're much worse. If Peyton Manning gets injured...no need to even finish this thought.

Disgraceful? That was 2007, when Bill Bellichick, who'd been needlessly running up the scores on blowout games all season, attempted to inflate his huge ego even more by having his Patriots plow through the end of the season so he could go down in history. Come Super Bowl time, his battered and exhausted O-line didn't stand a chance against your G-Men pass rush. Caldwell proved he has the chops to be a successful NFL coach by keeping his pride out of it and making the right decision, the one that will improve his chances of winning it all, just like the great Tony Dungy. Colts fans will forgive him when they beat the Vikings in February.
comments.subject: Unpopular but smart

comments.article:
The Colt's decision to tank the game was disgraceful and detrimental to the team.

You use the 2007 Patriots as evidence supporting your argument. You are ignoring the fact that the Giants who won the super-bowl that year had no bye-week in the playoffs that year and played hard from game 1 through 19. They could have taken game 16 off during the regular season to rest up for the play offs, but they didn't. They instead played and lost in an Epic game that gave New England it's perfect regular season.

Allow me to quote Teddy Bruschi, a member of the NE 2007 team and now ESPN analyst. He has been an integral part of 4 superbowl teams. This was his response to the Colt's decision and he is 100% correct.

"My question is: Rest for what? The playoffs?

The Colts already have a first-round bye. That is the time to rest.

There aren't many times in your life when you have a chance to do something that has never been done before. When you are faced with a challenge like that, my feeling is that you embrace it and see if you've got what it takes to conquer it.

That's the way we felt in New England. And yes, we lost the Super Bowl, but let me be clear: We lost the Super Bowl because the New York Giants played better than we did that day. It was not because we were tired and needed more rest."

In the NFL, winning teams play hard 100% of the time, they play to win and they do not take a break on the field. NFL teams are actually very close to each other in terms of talent. What separates winning teams and losing teams and what makes championship teams is the mental state of the team. Teams that let up or take games off are not winning teams.

And as an aside, there is no running up the score in the NFL. You do everything you can to secure the win. Were the Colts running up the score in 2004 when Peyton set the touchdown record?
comments.subject: Re: Unpopular but smart

comments.article:
As a long time Colts fan, I have never been more disgusted by my teams management than I am right now. I won't be surprised if we're one and done AGAIN this year.

Congrats on the win, now the Jets control their fate.

Dont blame Caldwell, he as Dungy was, is merely a puppet. Bill Pollian is the real ckicken**** here. Indy is in full on uproar and we all see the one and done coming. The year we won the superbowl we didn't rest. We palyed through with no bye. The one thing that gets me is the arrogance of not learning your lessons like we were taught in 05.
comments.subject: Colts Fan

comments.article:
I get that Sheridan doesn't have Spagnuolo's fire. But fire hasn't exactly made the Rams anything other than the worst team in the freaking league. "Spags" should be given another year, yes, but anything less than six wins in 2010 (how's that for high expectations?) is inexcusable. Especially with all the freaking high-ass draft picks we've amassed over the past few years.

For the 2010 draft ... rather than quarterback, I'm vacillating - looking at maybe taking that monster Suh from Nebraska with our vaunted overall number one pick. Giant middle-of-the-line everything-stoppers seem to be a pretty sure thing, with health being the x-factor. Though the Redskins backed up the Brinks truck to Albert Haynesworth's door and haven't exactly shown anything for it.

I dunno. Can Spags take Long and Suh and make them actually mean something? Ellie Manning's heroics or no, the Gints wouldn't have won that Super Bowl without that defensive line of theirs.
Hah, Suh isn't getting out of the top 5 dude. More than likely he will end up playing in Detroit.

Glad to see you not gloating too much about a gift. Even though the Dolphins lost so we weren't going anywhere anyway, I was indeed pretty steamed - couldn't believe the Colts did that given all of the implications. Haven't seen ESPN so I don't know what the commentators are saying but all of my usual support for the Colts given the Peyton SEC connection is certainly gone for this year. (Sorry about the Giants.)
